column7: Description
Being consistently spoken over or dismissed in meetings
Hearing others make sexist jokes at work
I have seen some colleagues generally excluded from opportunities to lead significant projects.
Viewed as an expert in my trade therefore not having much to offer in other areas of the organization.
At my last company I didn't advance as quickly as those who spent time going to after work events (both professional and happy-hour-types)
I am often the only minority within my peers
My work, and the direct results of my work, are not reflected in my performance reviews but my leadership and some peers take credit for them. I'm often the only woman in these situations.
Emphasis on observing specific religious holidays (xmas, others) when many of my peers don't celebrate them
Earlier in my career, I had my children and believe that I was not provided the same opportunities to take on key projects.  This considerably slowed my career advancement.
I am often asked to substantiate or prove statements where other male peers are not required to do the same
i have felt excluded as a woman where I was the only woman and some derogatory comments were made about women. everyone laughed and I was embarrassed. this took place years ago and not at *company*
Long-term employees are viewed as knowledgeable about the industry. My ideas are often not heard in a meeting when a white male gives the same suggestion everyone listens.

I have often experienced a much higher and almost insidious 'burden of proof' than my male peers- I often feel this is a communication challenge. I feel that the environment is not tolerant at all to learning different communication styles - if I can't 'manage up' I fail.  I see that for others (male) there is more forgiveness on this.
I have seen some colleagues who are seen as "do-ers" be passed over for promotions and not prepared for development and advancement.

I tend to feel like I am not able to advance objectives or obtain desired performance or support when I must collaborate with aggressive/unpleasant colleagues or superiors; I have feel like I have not advanced as far as I could have if I were a more aggressive personality
sometimes when in a meeting and references are made to sports I feel excluded because I don't follow any sports

Prior to joining *company*, clients of my former employer were not always as open to including a professional of my then-age and gender in work-related social events or other opportunities, even though my own employer was very eager to be inclusive.
I often have to speak up and compete for attention from managers with other male peers whose voice is stronger

I had been leading a key project for 2 years and had a junior white male come work for me.  After he joined my team, at both internal and external meetings, people in the room automatically spoke to him about the project and its status.  I had to have a direct conversation with my supervisor to ask that this unconscious bias be addressed and stopped.

My 'negatives', which are often referred to as 'emotional', 'less tactful', and 'combative' are brought up much more frequently than my contributions in performance and promotion discussions.  I see that the 'negatives' of my male counterparts seem to be more tolerable to my leadership.
Had suggestion and was ignored when a male counterpart made similar suggestion, it was recognized.
Assignments are not always distributed equitably, and those with applicable talents, skills or knowledge are not always given an opportunity to contribute.
I have been offered learning opportunities after other have completed them or passed on them
Often excluded overlooked from important conversations regarding strategic decisions. Management has difficulty assessing talent outside of a person's current role.
There is a senior manager, not mine, that favors extensively another manager in his/her group.  It is something that at times is very noticeable.

In my experience, *company* is great with inclusion regarding gender and race.  However, I have faced barriers as a result of where I am located geographically.  I have not been considered for promotional opportunities due to my location.
Early in my career, I've felt excluded based on a current role/title... it was as if you specialized in one area, all of your previous experience is discounted or not considered when problem solving
Being treated differently and feeling dismissed by external stakeholders when younger.

I believe I have not paid in both base and IC as well as my male colleagues.  In fact my prior boss at one point said, "You have a husband that is the primary income earner so it is okay to pay them more."

We have a 'command and control' culture where we intentionally exclude certain people in projects, decision-making and even in awareness.  I was often 'dinged' for bringing in the 'wrong people' to discussions earlier in my time here- inclusiveness is encouraged on the surface, but it can't include those participants that do not meet the leadership's criteria
I have a sense that male peers are compensated on a higher tier for the same job although their performance may be inferior

People assume all sorts of reasons why I may interrupt others, speak over others or seem like I am not engaged in meetings. I also hear people say I was talking to you and you ignored me. What they don't know, or remember for those who do know, is that I have lost hearing in one ear. With Zoom there are new challenges - where I can often see the light up square of who is speaking I can't as easily read lips or get cues right on when to speak. Wearing masks is now an even greater challenge to those of us that read lips! Talking about it is hard, and for those I have talked to I don't want to keep reminding them. I get judged for this, and have been told so, but it's hard to address. When I do share - I am amazed how many others also have this challenge! We don't talk enough about hearing challenges.
Excluded from critical business meetings due to gender.

I had been leading a key project for 2 years and had a junior white male come work for me. After he joined my team, at both internal and external meetings, people in the room automatically spoke to him about the project and its status. I had to have a direct conversation with my supervisor to ask that this unconscious bias be addressed and stopped.
Often overlooked or not included in strategic communications.  Leadership can often not see people outside of their current role.

I was in a meeting with a group of co-workers and at some point everyone besides me started laughing and looking at their phones as if they were all texting each other at the same time based off of what I was talking about.
Counsel for broker-dealers are not always as inclusive as *company* is with respect to females or younger professionals.

Gave a presentation to a group on issues occurring at a firm. The group was predominantly male and when the opportunity for feedback and questions came around. The feedback received was more comical and dismissed.
ideas are ignored until the are echoed from a male.

I was asked to be a part of a diversity project where I notice I was the only woman of color on the team. My perspectives, ideas and thoughts weren't heard and it seemed more so I was only chosen for one reason.
For certain department activities with staff, being told that I am a den mother in the department presumably because I'm a female.
Was the more senior person at a member firm meeting but firm treated subordinate as more senior since he was a male.
Often excluded or overlooked from important conversations regarding strategic decisions. Management has difficulty assessing talent outside of a person's current role.
Ideas are ignored until the are echoed by a male.
Skills are often seen as non-transferrable.
Certain groups who are not high-profile from an external perspective are over-looked for training, committees, etc.
Not having opportunity to speak until toward the end of a meeting
I am overlooked for promotional opportunities and growth/advancement.
I was given very little to do and staff seemed surprised when I asked for more.
I am often talked over, in meetings.
Ideas were discounted during meetings, felt like it was because of my perceived age and being female.
I have at times felt I was treated different, because I look young.
The extremely hierarchical, "vertical" structure has occasionally made me feel excluded.
When Christmas decorations (poinsettias, wreaths, etc) go up all over the office.
I'm sometimes ignored or spoken over in meetings.
I have been talked down to in senior leadership meetings despite being very knowledgeable about the topic being discussed.
I am often not included in projects.
I am in a specialty team within *company* in which the leadership has been, since inception, overwhelmingly white and male.
I have been treated as an equal, and looked to for my input.

Perception that there is no space for upward growth due to senior leadership being exclusively white. 

Leaders often confuse you with other people who have the same skin color.
I was excluded from meetings after being told what a great job I did by my previous manager. My awards were hidden and not mentioned to my department.
Interrupted or talked over in meetings.

I have in general great experience working at *company*. The management team is very open to diversity and inclusion.

However, I do see that all the senior leadership in my group is while male and we recently hired a white female to a leadership role.

This is actually good news but I would like to see some minorities get promoted to higher ranks.
I had an idea for improving a process which was ignored. The same idea was picked up and utilized when suggested by someone else.
Getting assignments that are typically assigned female
My manager excluded me from the beginning phase of a project that is one of my 2020 job goals for reasons she did not make clear to me.
I have been described as "aggressive." (I do not think a man would have received this feedback under the circumstances)

The same group of individuals are typically picked for high profile projects and assignments. Valuable Skills and promotional opportunities are therefore not developed in other employees, perpetuating the problem.
Not being included in meetings but responsible for the work product.
For much of my time in my department, my group seemed to receive case assignments that were far less technical than what other groups were receiving.
My annual review was very positive, but not reflected in compensation or recognition
My experiences of exclusion have occurred not because of personal characteristics but because my job/department was not valued by senior management and other departments.
Being interrupted in meetings
I had a co-worker tell me that I preferred a vendor proposal because it was pretty.

When I first started, I was excluded from conversations that I felt I could have added value because of my age/experience. It became a bit of a "vicious cycle" in that I wasn't included due to what was perceived as a lack of experience and couldn't gain experience due to the lack of inclusion.
Unequal recognition of accomplishments.
"Bullied" by male colleagues.
I was not asked to participate in a project which required travel as I had young children and it was "assumed" I wouldn't want to travel.
Lack of Black or African American managers
Leaders and others often confuse you with other people who have the same skin color.
The firm does not give pro-rated bonuses to employees hired in the 4th quarter. However, the company does provide pro-rated bonuses to employees hired in quarters 1-3. Unfair.
I am selected due to my experience for training and questions, but not recognized with promotional opportunities.
As a female, I feel like I'm being held to a higher standard for promotion than my male colleagues
Being micro managed by manager.
I was treated in a disrespectful, rude manner by a colleague and no action was taken to remedy it.
Perception that there is no space for upward growth due to senior leadership being exclusively white.

I feel invisible, marginalized, and disrespected. I have been excluded from emails and communications. I have been talked over and my ideas, suggestions and observations dismissed without being considered.
When my group moved from one department to another, I felt as though I was demoted because my decision-making authority was reduced.
Not being asked to go to a group lunch
My manager uses comments like "we want fresh and innovative perspectives" often when I share my perspective.
Pay effected negatively due to maternity leave. Annual percentage raise decreased...effectively compounding the disadvantage for the rest of my career.
During the COVID-19 pandemic it was extremely difficult for me to keep up my productivity while having my child at home.
This is less prominent than in the past, but there are barriers to career advancement for people in the District offices compared to the New York and Maryland offices
I have heard anecdotes of women's input being ignored in the meetings and the entire team acknowledges an idea presented by a male, even if it is the same idea.
In the past, I was not always included in certain meetings or phone calls that I thought I should have been included in.

There is very little of no opportunity for promotion in my current role. On a regular basis I a responsible for performing multiple task beyond the scope of my job but am not compensated for it.  It is an exclusion issue in that persons in roles such as mine are doing a job that we are not recognized and compensated for. No promotion is available, so we have hit a ceiling.  There is little to no opportunity to transfer to other roles.  We see our co-workers promoted for their performance, but there is no promotion for staff such as me.
I have found that women and minorities have to do substantially more in order to compete and obtain the same respect and opportunities as males and non-minorities.
I am excluded.
I often feel favortism is shown in the department to younger white staff members.

Excluded from leadership meetings. There's inconsistency of who's invited to this meeting. Others at my same level are included but me and others are not. These are the opportunities to consistently meet and have "face time" with senior leaders in the dept.

I used to be part of a team where the male manager regularly went to lunch with only the men on the team. The two women on the team (myself included) were never invited, This is still the culture in this specific office location.
Struggles with coping to work from home due to myself being a working parent and having a co-parent and child with high needs / mental health needs
I feel I've been overlooked for qualified opportunities.
Denied opportunity for promotion in the past, while male colleagues similarly situated were given more opportunities.
My ideas and contributions are not recognized or acknowledged
I have not been nominated to serve on important committees while my female colleagues have.
In Toastmasters there was one higher up that would always dismiss my ideas, and I felt it was similar with other women's ideas.
Unable to get further ahead in my career path and there has been no indication of why
I sometime feel that my contributions are not sufficiently recognized.
I feel included.  Sometimes I am one of few women in meetings, but I haven't felt treated differently.
Being ignored or overlooked to provide input during meetings by male colleagues and leaders

At one point I was the only woman on a team of 9.  Many opportunities were assigned to my male colleagues before more mundane assignments were assigned to me, even though my previous work experiences would have suggested otherwise.  I felt I was not provided opportunities because I was female.
In a litigation team of four (two men and two women), the other woman and I were constantly talked over and talked down to by the male members of the team.  The other woman has left the company.
There were times during meetings with lunch offered when I felt like I had to bring my own lunch, because no one thought to order something vegetarian/vegan.

My immediate supervisor is a white male. He is on the DLC and considers himself woke. However, one day, I asked for assistance with an inquiry that I was unfamiliar with and he mocked me and said you have two advanced degrees --- more than I have (he does not have an advanced degree) and you should be able to figure it out. I had not had the opportunity to be exposed to those other business areas so I was unfamiliar with the subject matter. Other members of my team who are YOUNG and WHITE appear to have more opportunities and access to projects that give them exposure to other areas of *company* business operations. In other conversations,
Offers to contribute are ignored and dismissed. My skills are under-utilized.
Not considered as valuable because my college degree was not in the same field as 'typical' for the job.
Offered development opportunities and achieve goals but there is limited promotion opportunities
My manager doesn't share information with team members so my coworkers and I have to compare notes in order to get the complete information set we need to do our work.
It is very difficult to get promoted when you are not part of the buddy buddy system at *company*.
I am not taken seriously in meetings and my opinions are brushed off as being too positive and/or naieve.
not being brought into upper management meetings
Not considered for a promotion/denied an interview despite being qualified.  This occurred after I asked questions about work/life balance due to my childcare situation.
I was told that I needed to be softer in my written communication, but then when I requested an example, in review of my email's, he could not identify any examples.

My particular personality type (introverted and analytical) receives less recognition than outspoken and assertive individuals. The "goals" for our group seem to try to mold individuals into a particular type of person rather than value the diverse skill sets that exist on my team.
Peers say things that are stereotypes.

I have been told that my voice is too loud and my demeanor "scares" people. I really make and effort to keep my voice down and it is not my intention to come off as unfriendly, I think my face just have a naturally "mean" look maybe.  I try really hard to be friendly with everyone.  I feel like the problem is that I am not 
latin-american like many others in my office as my cultural upbringing is just different from theirs.
As a woman, I am being paid less than my male colleagues with the same title. Also, I'm assigned more work.
I was told "you are sick a lot" because I have bouts of fibromyalgia and need to flex my work hours when it hits. I always get my work done and get highest evals.
In the past, I was not always copied on emails that I feel I should have been.

Despite having more practical and *company* experience at a particularly high-level and highly visible surveillance, I was bypassed in favor of someone with zero relevant experience. He did, however, appear to have the support and friendship of the decision-makers that assigned him to that role.
not promoted
Opinions not sought - while those of male colleagues were - in meetings
I have occasionally experienced people interrupting in meetings.  I at times attribute this to being a slow, analytical thinker.
I sometimes feel that I am not recognized sufficiently for my contributions.
Despite that I have two advanced degrees, and working above and beyond my job description, I have been passed over for promotions.
There have been times when hard work and good outcomes have not been sufficiently recognized.
I often get feedback from my direct reports regarding my interactions with them.  Much of the feedback is related to items that differentiate me from the standard "female" ideal set of behaviors.
At times, in meetings with my manager and his peers or superiors, my views are not solicited by manager and if I offer them they are not considered or I may be interrupted.
I feel that I am treated differently because I am married with no children.
My manager sends texts at 7 pm in the evening and expects immediate answers.
Routinely see other individuals with less experience promoted.
When I make a point during meetings (as a woman), men often come in after me and restate my thoughts as if the idea isn't really "said" until they restate it.
Lack of formal recognition while co workers are recognized for much lesser accomplishments.

I have not been afforded the opportunity to participate in strategic meetings with executives in my own organization where men at the same level and less knowledge than i have on the subject have been asked to participate.
Discrepancy in pay between tenured employees and new hires.
My superior is sometimes rude towards me during meetings.
Within my own unit, I am consistently passed over for a promotion or a management position even though I have two master degrees and have experience as a supervisor.
Ideas were discounted during meetings, felt like it was because of my perceived age and being female.
As a bisexual in a male-female partnership, I face constant assumptions about the nature about my sexuality (people always assume that I am straight)
Feedback and opinion was not valued. I felt that it was because I was the least experience out of the group.
A coworker has made several comments along the lines of "xyz makes sense because you're gay."
after ideas are presented they are disregarded, then repeated by a counterpart of another gender and accepted but not accepted
I feel that my Dept and *company* as a whole is not always transparent

Being gay feels fairly isolating. I don't know if others are gay in my office, even though I've been there a long time, but it has never felt like a safe place to be openly gay, and I think that some people may know I'm gay, but it feels like I do ongoing compartmentalizing to feel more the "same as everyone else" and do my job - it means that I don't make friendships, but I am a productive contributor and have been rewarded for that.
I have been passed over for other higher and/level positions in other departments as well. Even though I qualify for a position, I do not even get a call for an interview.
I have taken a large amount of training to enhance my knowledge, but it is not recognized.
Although I currently feel that my skills are put to good use, there have been many times in the past when I saw a significant problem in this area.
Lack of female or people of color in executive positions.
My manager sends rude and condescending emails sometimes.
I feel I have received less compensation than my peers due to my status as a single mom.
I have had several equity adjustments over the years, making me clearly aware that I've been under paid
Several people were recommended for a highly coveted training experience at Wharton but a selection bias exists with regard to minorities.
I feel like I've been overlooked for opportunities that I qualify for do to my age.

Overthinking what I say in a meeting (may be a personal problem), being interrupted, not being taken seriously from firms we regulate, I had a really bad experience while on site at a firm, the CCO was very disrespectful the entire time I was there, he wouldn't answer my questions, argued with my guidance, even called me stupid, etc... I later found that the men who worked with this individual did not have this experience. I escalated this to my manager he told me to just keep on being nice. My manager did not intervene.

I have volunteered for multiple events and been active across *company* in different aspects. I have voiced my desire to get promoted and yet it took over four years to get go from a level 46 to a level 47, while at the same time seeing other individuals do less work and volunteering for events and somehow they were promoted within 2 years. 
After a number of years after attaining a level 47,I finally applied for EM/AD positions and still have seen others that appear to be friendlier get those positions. It feels like it is more a function of who you know than the work you put out in some instances. 
It just feels like promotions are predetermined. most of these experiences were prior to the transformation and I hope that will not be the case going forward.

Because my boss wants to show his boss that he can promote women, I was passed over for a promotion in favor of less experienced, less talented, less successful female candidates for management positions.
In the past, I have had the perception that my compensation has not been comparable to a male counterpart at my grade level.
Being passed over for lateral moves in the organization.

Comments uttered can be insensitive about other nations and cultures, as it relates to my own identity and to others. For example, criticizing a country as a whole can invoke feelings of exclusion if one who identifies with a culture that originates in that country.

My pursuit of a reasonable work accommodation was initially mishandled by all levels of management in my group. It has had a lasting and detrimental impact on my self-esteem and my feeling of acceptance at this organization.
I am treated differently by my manager than are my male peers.  My facts and opinions are challenged more frequently,  I am interrupted more frequently.
Routinely take on extra training opportunities that fall above my current level without this resulting in recognition or advancement.
There is no growth opportunity for my previous position at *company*.
Not a recent example but under prior management over 9 years ago. At times recognition was fleeting.
language in a meeting refers to langauge around individuals with special needs in terms that are offensive
In a meeting with approximately 50 people, a VP at *company* said that MLK day was not a real holiday and that we shouldn't get the day off.

I am paid the same or less than my peers with similar or less experience.  I believe that both my gender and age play a role in this.  Especially, since I have years more experience than many of my peers.

I have received hostility from "customers" in response to normal inquiries required for my job.  The individual was accusatory and condescending during our interactions, but pleasant and understanding when redirected to a male supervisor.  The supervisor handled the situation with the customer well, but was skeptical when I suggested the customer was more hostile towards women on the team (including our director).
I have had older male colleagues talk down to me and assume I do not know something. I perceive this to be based on my age and gender.

I look younger than I am. One time at a regional management meeting, someone told me they thought I was in high school and was there to delivery the coffee. This statement was made after I had already introduced myself as a *company* employee.
promotions are not being made based on most skilled
It appears that our group is looked as less important in our department as our work is different from the majority of the department.
Substantive leadership opportunities (Wharton, Inspired to Lead) are typically awarded to men, and the criteria for selection is not clear.
Peers perpetually scheduling work meetings that are difficult for me to attend (I have a family) out of 9-5 working hours, and feeling judgement for it.

I have attended group meetings for various reasons -- overview of salaries, voluntary retirement, etc. My view is that Human Resources, now called People Solutions, has a very disrespectful attitude at times.
Assigned less high profile projects than male counterparts with same experience
Only the most senior managers are successful in being promoted.
During the COVID-19 pandemic it was extremely difficult for me to keep up the productivity while having my child at home.
I feel like more is expected of me to gain a promotion due to my gender and because I look young.

A lot of attention is given to racial diversity and inclusion issues, rightfully and deservedly, but not nearly enough to gender diversity and inclusion, which continues to be a significant issue for women in the organization.
Everyone is nice but most people around me are Caucasian and I generally feel I do not belong.

There have been several discussions between women colleagues about the fact that female canidates are not permitted to negotiate salaries when hired but managers will negotiate salaries with male hires.

I interviewed for a promotion and was told that there would be a second round of interviews with the next-level manager.  The second round did not occur, and I was passed over for a white male with a year and a half experience at *company*.  I had 16 years experience at the time.
I have been perceived as being bossy rather than assertive as my male colleagues are often considered.
I have been excluded from taking advantage of workplace flexibility offered to others as a single mother.

I have felt that my opportunities for advancement have been stifled by the fact that I am an individual contributor and don't manage staff. This is a factor of the organization of my department and the rules of the firm in general, not because of personal characteristics.
My work is not recognized sometimes by the manager. I will do a job but will not be acknowledged when that job is presented publicly.
I sometimes get pigeon-holed into performing certain tasks based on my accounting background rather than being exposed to new areas.
Management and supervisory changes are made without communication or explanation.

The VP head of our department has obvious favorites that he values and often highlights for the work that they do. However, those people are often given access to assignments and projects that give them the opportunity to shine. They are predominantly young and white. One day, my colleague and I were attending our staff meetings and during the meeting, the VP blasts a project that I collaborated on with another colleague (older, white male, gay). He didn't even bother to tell us that he had issues with the project first. He blasts us in front of everyone in the department.

I have dietary restrictions due to my disability.  These restrictions are not accommodated (which is fine), but I am frequently the subject of comments by co-workers about why I am not eating at an event that features food.
I have been passed over for jobs that I have applied for and extremely qualified for while younger employees have been selected for those positions.
Inconsistency in the rate of promotions across peer groups.

I have been in securities industry for many years. Throughout most of my career, I have not been compensated financially,not respected,not been given work opportunities that my male counterparts have been given. *company* has provided the equality and respect  that has been missing.
Work done by the majority is always highlighted and recognized whereas the minorities have to do twice as much to receive the same recognition.
Not being seriously considered for CRPC programming.
work-life options not equally offered to all
being talked over in meetings

During a training class, I was ridiculed by a peer for not promptly showing a different way to search for information using one of our internal systems. Management was in the training class, but they did not say a thing to the co-worker.
I am not given chances to work on new projects or initiatives.
Holiday celebrations that I don't celebrate being the only times that a department has celebrations, i.e. parties, paid meals, etc.

I was the victim of domestic violence which escalated to the point of my abuser be arrested. A court order prevented my abuser from seeing our child as both my child were attacked. I was scheduled to travel for work the following week with a team and offered to complete my work offsite as I had no child care. Instead of allowing me to assist remotely,I was removed from the exam, and other team members had to pick up additional assignments. I later learned from a colleague that was present that the other team members openly discussed  my extremely private and hurtful experience and the team's consensus was there is "never an excuse" to miss an exam and I should consider finding another job.

At one point worked for individual who valued aggressive, outspoken, hard-driving individuals in leadership position.  As a calm, people-oriented, positive person, I felt that by not fitting the model I was being overlooked for opportunity.
At one point in my career my salary was not on par with male teammates that were performing identical job functions. (Thankfully, that has been corrected)
I haven't experienced too much exclusion. I feel very grateful for *company*'s Inclusion. However, some people may feel excluded in certain areas due to a lack of transparency? Not sure.
Not enough career opportunities.

I look younger than I am. One time at a regional management meeting, someone told me they thought I was in high school and was there to delivery the coffee. This statement was made after I had already introduced myself as a *company* employee.

As the company reorganizes and offers new opportunities for advancement for the first time for many of us, I feel excluded from possible advances due to my older age, even though I have vast experience and knowledge due to my tenure and participation in many special assignments and programs.
The comments felt a little condescending.
I feel that it doesn't matter how hard I work, I can not get promoted.
Ceilings have been set prohibiting promotion and growth.

Women are hired and promoted on their proven work experience. Men are promoted on their potential. Men are hired with less experience and paid more at the outset. As a result my loyalty to the company is not rewarded as I continue to prove myself. The men around me continue to get better pay and more respect.  As a young mother back in the 90's before remote work, I had a flexible boss that allowed me to bring my baby to work for part of the day. Newborns sleep a lot. It didn't last due to the complaints from anonymous peers that felt if they were not given those same opportunities then I should not be given the opportunity.  Instead of embracing it and making forward progress in this area to promote work life balance for young mothers and fathers, they ended it and provided no other option. I had to scramble to find childcare.
I have struggled with how to "bring my whole self to work," specifically as it relates to my mental health disorders

Hiring is a complex and competitive. However, working hard and checking all of the boxes on education, experience, knowledge, skill, ability is never enough.

I have witness new hires that have no industry experience or less knowledge, but they seem to continue to get hired and promoted. I have trained individuals that are currently promoted to higher levels than me. Happy to see them succeed, but sometimes I feel I am an underutilized talent, which makes *company* less than it can be.

Ready and qualified.
Although consistently reviewed as "distinguished", i am not given opportunities to take on career opportunities beyond those I have had for a number of years, even though i have asked for them.
People are encouraged to take time off during this time. However, taking a day off means using the time to take care of kids, not for myself.
I don't think I am compensated equally to my male peers.
My compensation has been negatively affected due to the long tenure that I have been here
recognition not given equally to all for successful completion of assignments
I once realized a male colleague doing the exact same job with similar experience earned more.

In the last 10 years my group has only hired internal candidates. There is a hive-mind effect because of that. Everyone thinks the same. Women and minorities and minority women are excluded, largely. The leadership cannot relate to feeling excluded or silenced.
Employees who have substantial time in grade (older workers) are seeing benefits cut. Examples: pension, service anniversary awards, IC/merit opportunity.

It feels as though I have to work much harder than my counterparts to be viewed in the same way related to contributions. When I came into *company* I had over seven years of experience and various securities licenses (e.g., 7,24,65,66), but I was brought in at the same level as someone with little to no years of experience.

Even advancement and salary appears to be weighted not by contribution but by a skewed expectation. If feels as though I have to work 10 times harder just to advance at the same pace of my peers.
I am a lower grade than every other person in my group performing the same job.
In the past, I feel that I have been passed over for a promotion for which I was qualified for reasons outside of my control.

Some members of management, seem to favor people to who conform to the traditional  professional look that includes traditional gender expression and clothing, ideal body weight, makeup for women, etc.

This may not be exclusion, but I feel it's inconsiderate to mandate that all workers have their cameras on during weekly meetings. The world has been shutdown for a little while and not everyone can throw their hair into a ponytail and look presentable.
Programs are software are not made available to everyone to encourage growth and new skills.
I do not feel HR is as transparent as they can could be regarding compensation. Therefore I feel more vulnerable to nor fair pay.
Siloed structure disallows movement between departments without having to take several steps back in career progression.
Although I feel that my current supervisor respects me, I have worked under other supervisors who often showed a lack of respect for me and others similarly situated.
